greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = (2^(A003558(n)) - A332433(n))/(2*n+1), for n >= 0.
comment: Only for n=0 with A003558(0) = 1 only the minimal solution for a(0), namely 1, for sign A332433(0) = +1 is recorded here.
For n >= 1 only one sign qualifies in A003558(n).

A comment on the iteration of f(x) = x^2 - 2 (called R(2, x) in A127672) with seed rho(n) := 2*cos(Pi/n) for odd n >= 3, used in the comment from _Gary W. Adamson_, Sep 06 2011 in A065941. The proof that the cycle length coincides with A003558(n) is done by using the known formulas, for integers k and m: (i) R(k, m*x) = R(k*m, x), (ii) R(-k, x) = R(k, x), and the periodicity formula (iii) R(j, rho(n)) = R(+/-(j + k*2*n), rho(n)), j >= 0, k integer, n odd >= 3. The iterations are then R(2^q, rho(n)), for q >= 1. The primitive period length P(n) is obtained from R(2^(P(n)+1), rho(n)) = R(2^1, rho(n)) = R(+-(2 + k*2*n), rho(n)), that is 2^P(n) = +-(1 + k*n) or 2^P(n) == +-1 (mod n) with the least P(n), hence P(n) = A003558(n).
link: Wolfdieter Lang, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
results.author: _Wolfdieter Lang_, Feb 17 2020
